put.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: to move something to a particular place or position, especially using your hands
put.translation[0].definitions[0].exampl: He put the coffee on the table.
Where did you put the programmes?
put.translation[0].definitions[1].defini: to make someone be in a situation or have a feeling
put.translation[0].definitions[1].exampl: Don’t put yourself into a situation you can’t handle.
I don’t want to put you in danger.
Pit closures have put thousands of miners out of a job (=made them lose their job).
A knee injury put him out of action for three months.
The long delay had put us all in a bad mood.
put somebody in a good/bad etc mood
His boss resigned and Murphy was put in charge.
put.translation[0].definitions[2].defini: to write or print something or to make a mark with a pen or pencil
put.translation[0].definitions[2].exampl: Put your name at the top of each answer sheet.
He put his signature to the contract  (=he signed it to show he agreed with it).
put.translation[0].definitions[3].defini: to say or write something using words in a particular way
put.translation[0].definitions[3].exampl: So it was an accident, an ‘act of God’ if you want to put it like that.
When women joined the organization, it ‘took on a new look', as news reports put it.
It is hard to put into words (=express) how I feel now.
He’s not very musical, to put it mildly (=he’s not musical at all).
We get on each other’s nerves, to put it bluntly (=to say exactly what I mean).
It’s fairly risky. Or to put it another way (=say it in different words), don’t try this at home.
The subject matter makes the painting a little, how shall I put it (=how can I say it politely?), undesirable for public display.
put.translation[0].definitions[4].defini: to ask a question or make a suggestion, especially to get someone’s opinion or agreement
put.translation[0].definitions[4].exampl: Can I put a question to you?
I put it to you that this proposal has to be considered.
He put the proposal to his wife.
put a proposition/proposal/case etc to somebody
The budget was put before the board of directors.
put.translation[0].definitions[5].defini: to make someone or something work or do something, or to use it
put.translation[0].definitions[5].exampl: a scheme to put unemployed people to work on government construction projects
If you have a spare room, put it to work for you – take in a lodger.
Computer games are being put to use in the classroom.
We put 15 rain jackets to the test (=we tested them).
put.translation[0].definitions[6].defini: to consider something as having a particular level of importance or quality
put.translation[0].definitions[6].exampl: A recent poll put Dr Martens among the world’s top thirty designer labels.
Some companies put profit before safety.
The job’s important to him, but he puts his family first.
put.translation[0].definitions[7].defini: to arrange for someone to go to a place, or to make them go there
put.translation[0].definitions[7].exampl: Put the boys to bed around eight o'clock.
The company is putting in new management.
Pneumonia put him in the hospital for a week.
put.translation[0].definitions[8].defini: to throw a shot (=a heavy metal ball) in a sports competition
put.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 4: to say or write something using words in a particular way
put.translation[0].note_box[0].sections[: well
Sorry, I’m not putting it very well.
simply
Put simply, our aim is to create art.
succinctly
A Russian economist put it most succinctly: ‘People do not care about carbon.’
mildly
His theory is controversial, to put it mildly.
bluntly/crudely/plainly
I would put it more bluntly. I think you are wallowing in self-pity.
delicately
He had been drunk, or as Hilton delicately put it, ‘talkative’.
cleverly
I didn't agree with her, but she put her argument so cleverly that I was almost persuaded.
put something another way
The dress was too small for me, or, to put it another way, I was too big for it.
put something this/that way
Let me put it this way - she's not as young as she was.
put something like that/this
‘He's been completely irresponsible.’ ‘I wouldn’t put it quite like that.’
put something into words
She couldn’t put her feelings into words.
how shall I/we put it?
Mr Lewis is now – how shall we put it? – hardly the influence he once was.
put.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 7: to ask a question or make a suggestion, especially to get someone’s opinion or agreement
put.translation[0].note_box[1].sections[: I will be putting that very question to her.
I’ve a proposition to put to you.
You should put that point to the Chancellor.
He wanted to put his case to the full committee.
I put it to him that what we needed was some independent advice.
put.translation[0].note_box[2].sections[: to move something to a particular place
I’ve put the wine in the fridge.
Where have you put my grey shirt?
to put something somewhere carefully
‘It’s beautiful, ’ he said, placing it back on the shelf.
lay
to put someone or something down carefully on a flat surface
He laid all the money on the table.
She laid the baby on his bed.
to carefully put something in a suitable position
Position the microphone to suit your height.
Troops were positioned around the city.
slip
to put something somewhere with a quick movement
He slipped his arm around her waist.
Carrie quickly slipped the money into her bag.
shove
to put something into a space or container quickly or carelessly
Shove anything you don’t want in that sack.
I’ve ironed those shirts so don’t just shove them in a drawer.
stick
to put something somewhere quickly or carelessly
I stuck the address in my pocket and I can’t find it now.
Could you bung those clothes in the washing machine?
dump
to put something down somewhere in a careless and untidy way
Don’t just dump all your bags in the kitchen.
People shouldn’t dump rubbish at the side of the street.
pop
to quickly put something somewhere, usually for a short time
Pop it in the microwave for a minute.
thrust
to put something somewhere suddenly or forcefully
‘Hide it, ’ he said, thrusting the watch into her hand.
to put something into a liquid
dip
to put something into a liquid for a very short time and take it out again
She dipped her hand in the water to see how hot it was.
Prawns are delicious dipped in a spicy sauce.
plunge
to put something quickly, firmly, and deeply into a liquid
Plunge the pasta into a pan of boiling water.
I had to plunge my arm in up to the elbow to reach the keys.
dunk
to put something such as a piece of bread or cake into a hot drink or soup before eating it
I love biscuits dunked in coffee.
immerse
to put something deep into a liquid so that it is completely covered
If the plant’s leaves look dry, immerse the roots in water for a while.
put.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: to offer a proposal, plan etc to a group of people which they can accept or reject
put.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: The latest offer will be put to the negotiating committee this afternoon.
put.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: to sign a letter, document etc saying that you agree with what is written in it
put.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: another name for PUT OPTION (=the right to sell shares etc at a particular price within a specific period of time)
put.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: In-the-money puts are options where the price at which the holder can sell the stock is well above the current market price of the shares.
Japanese players are holding a large amount of dollar puts at 132.4 yen.
